passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 79.00 EUR | Price: 63.10 EUR

We remain positive on Greenergy despite its very strong \(90\%\) share price performance year- to- date following a bullish CMD (see our note: Bring it On and on). We think management remains conservative on guidance (see our note: On and on the road with) especially on asset sales (a potential catalyst) whilst ongoing updates on execution should sustain performance. We see the recent \(18\%\) pullback from the €74+ all- time high of June as offering a particularly attractive Buying opportunity. With a higher €79 PO suggesting c.25% upside potential, Greenergy remains our top pick in Renewables.

We remain cautious on renewables overall (see our note: Bloated Al- ppetite), but storage is on the rise. We believe Greenergy is well- placed to capitalise on this theme given its: (a) first- mover advantage; (b) vertically integrated model improving time to market; and (c) pipeline with good visibility vs new entrants facing long connection queues. While this economic moat is not completely watertight, we still think its advantage is innate and structural based on an excellent track- record, and would expect the market to reward this.

We see (a) accelerated execution; (b) crystallised asset rotation; and (c) an augmented pipeline as a virtuous circle for growth. Solar is also a buyer's market, meaning deals could bring forward the hybridisation pipeline, and banks are now more comfortable financing storage. We also think that the existing plan is conservative, particularly with asset rotations at 1.3x (against 1.5x achieved historically) with each 0.1x worth an extra €150m+ in our pipeline model, or \(9\%\) of current capitalisation.

At our PO Greenergy would trade on 10x EV/EBITDA 2y forward for \(>50\%\) CAGR, and 8x for \(40\%\) still in 2027. We find this compelling against clean energy transition names trading on 8x for \(7\%\) (and EDPR on 12x for \(10\%\) ) or utilities on 8x for \(4\%\) . While we acknowledge execution risks given the strong upscaling of the business, we think delivery so far has been excellent. We revise our EBITDA forecasts by \(+5\%\) on higher WACCs; also we change our valuation methodology from an equal weighted SOTP on DCF and EV/EBITDA multiples to a- solely DCF- based SOTP (see details on page 8). Our PO thus rises from €72.5 to €79. We are \(35\%\) above consensus on 2027- 28E.

We reiterate our Buy rating on Greenergy despite a very strong \(90\%\) share price performance year- to- date following a bullish CMD (see our note: Bring it On and on). We think management remains conservative on guidance (see our note: On and on the load with) ongoing updates on execution should sustain performance with new asset rotations a potential surprise to the upside. We see the recent \(18\%\) pullback from the €74+ all- time high of June offering as a particularly attractive buying opportunity. With a higher €79 PO suggesting c. \(25\%\) upside, Greenergy remains our top pick in Renewables.

The share price of our covered European pure- play renewables has gone up by \(+10\%\) (market cap weighted) since the beginning of the year. This is already an extremely strong performance compared to the \(- 28\%\) seen in 2024 and \(- 14\%\) on average across 2021, 2022 and 2023. We would argue that the sector's recent performance can largely be ascribed to changes in US policies, but it also reflects a more bullish view on storage more specifically for Greenergy and a strong CMD in May (see our note: Greenergy: Bring it On and On). Greenergy shares are now up \(>50\%\) since US tariffs were announced in April, and \(>90\%\) year- to- date. We share management's bullish view on storage, and see the recent pullback to €62 from the highs of €74 per share in early June as a particularly enhance buying opportunity (see Exhibit 1).
Exhibit 1: European renewables' recent performance has been largely dependent on US policy Selected European renewables and indexes performance (100 = 1 Jan 2024) Aug 23 to Aug 25
Source: BofA Global Research, Bloomberg

We are conscious that the Greenergy story might have seemed somehow subdued in the past few weeks, following a bullish CMD in May, all- time highs in early June, and the subsequent placement in mid- June of 1.58m shares (about \(5.5\%\) of total capital and \(15\%\) of free float) at €61 by the founder and senior management - around which level the shares are now trading.

The company is still expected to announce new PPAs for phase 6 and 5 of the flagship Oasis Atacama project. We consider this slightly late for phase 6 given an already ready- to- build phase in Q2 2025 (and Q4 for phase 5). However, management might have been

focusing on signing PPAs for its new Central Oasis project instead (announced at the May CMD for 3.8GWh, compared to 4.3GWh for phase 6 and 5 of Oasis Atacama). It also aims to get its first hybrid project in Spain ready-to-build in Q4 2025 (for 0.7GWh) and a first standalone battery project in Spain ready-to-build in Q1 2025 (for 0.6GWh).

As such, we still expect Greenergy's equity story to be driven by execution progress in flagship projects and the overall pipeline in the medium term. But we see more rapid upside potential - to above company guidance and above our own expectations - should asset rotations materialise sooner rather than later, as we detail in a following section.

We continue to see upside risk to guidanceWe continue to argue that Greenergy's run-rate EBITDA guidance of €450- 500m by 2027 is conservative. We forecast EBITDA of over €480m in 2027 and €725m in 2028 with an implied run- rate of €495m (using a 2027- 28 average and excluding capital gains, the simplest way to reconcile to the guidance perimeter).

Consensus is now close to €450m over the 2027- 28 period: we see a upside risk of at least \(10\%\) and potentially even more should consensus already include capital gains (no granularity available).

We are conscious that we have higher capex figures in our forecasts. However, there are some differences in perimeter (namely GW assumed). We still expect capacity additions beyond 2027 and 2028 (meaning development capex for assets with CoD in 2029 and beyond) and as we model asset rotations on a total enterprise value basis. Meanwhile, Greenergy might be considering only equity recycling thus excluding project debt. Nevertheless, we think our forecasts reflect the economics underpinning renewables development and they still suggest to us upside potential to Greenergy's guidance.
Exhibit 2: We believe Greenergy's current guidance is relatively conservative Greenergy 2027 guidance against BofA and consensus
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report, Bloomberg
Back when Greenergy shares were trading above €70, investors we spoke to were asking if the 'easy' gains were not done, and if valuation was not becoming a bit too 'rich'.

We still see upside risk to guidance, as we show in the previous section, which is reinforced by management comments that the existing plan is conservative on some assumptions such as: (a) capex, with ongoing technological improvements; (b) remuneration, with upside from capacity markets; and (c) valuation, with assumed asset rotations at 1.3x vs 1.5x achieved historically (see our note: Greenergy: On and On the road with).

We show sensitivities to fair value from our base case in our DCF pipeline model in the next exhibit. A bigger, better and faster pipeline could add +/- €16 per share to our SOTP (DCF- based) fair value, including bigger and better asset rotations.

We use the below screen (see Exhibit 4) to plot our own estimate of operational assets and pipeline values (blue bars) against trading levels (red dots) and as a share of our PO (rebased to 100 at the red dotted line). For EDPR, our PO is mostly composed of operational assets (big dark, blue bar) and suggest that the market overestimates operational value and/or pipeline valuation and/or underestimates liabilities (on which we have a more conservative and granular view than consensus, we understand, as we do not limit our scope to net financial debt). This supports our Underperform rating on EDPR (and equally on Acciona Energia).

For Grenergy, our PO is mostly composed of pipeline to 2030, with operational assets a net negative given high capex and debt phasing in the Atacama project, as well as central costs for growth in the overall pipeline. Bottom- line, though, this screen is but one of several tools we use to inform our ratings (Exhibit 4)
Exhibit 4: Grenergy's value lies in its pipeline given capex, debt phasing and central costs for growth BofA renewables pure-players BofA SOTP valuation mix vs market valuation (as % PO)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates Note: Grenergy operational value is negative from high capex and debt phasing in the Atacama project

We use the below screen (see Exhibit 5) to plot our coverage based on Bloomberg consensus valuation and numbers compared to our own debt adjustments (meaning multiples are more expensive than the Bloomberg EV bridge) and forecasts (higher than consensus as we fully model pipeline growth). We further plot implied valuation multiples at our PO. We argue that EDPR - and Acciona Energia - are looking more expensive, which supports our Underperform rating on both.

However, for Grenergy we would argue the relative value is good to excellent. It has a significant growth profile (off the chart given the strong \(>50\%\) EBITDA CAGR we forecast near- term) but is attractively priced especially factoring in execution risks, with both good delivery and communication from management.

Exhibit 5: We think Grenergy offers a compelling valuation given high growth at a decent price European renewables vs Utility sector and Clean Energy Transition index 2y forward EV/EBITDA and CAGR (Bloomberg consensus)

Source: BofA Global Research estimates, Bloomberg Note: We use 2025-27 CAGR for our coverage and indexes, except 2024-26 for SXXP (data errors) we restate Acciona Energia to remove 2025 hydro one-offs. Grenergy and Solaria are off charts as outliers given strong EBITDA growth.

Grenergy needs to invest a significant amount of capital, with a €3.5bn capex plan for the next three years that is double its capitalisation today. While underlying earnings are minimal today, the company has completely changed scope and evolved from an asset- developer to an asset- owner, making it difficult to comment on leverage (see Exhibit 6) or multiple on a current year basis. Valuation is already attractive, and even more on a forward- looking basis, with EV/EBITDA multiple at a compelling \(
Exhibit 6: Leverage is impacted by frontloaded capex ... Grenergy net financial debt (€m) ranges from €1,000-4,500mn and IFRS leverage (x) forecasts range from c.7-5x in 2022-29E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report
Exhibit 7: ... and we see a very compelling valuation in 2-3 years Grenergy EBITDA (€0.5mn to €900mn) and EV/EBITDA (x) forecasts at c. 5-7X in 2022-29E
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

We have made marginal revisions to our Grenergy model, mostly fine- tuning to reflect changes we made across the sector on WACC (rates, equity premium and debt premium), which impact our operational and pipeline model as well as EBITDA forecasts. We now use an overall WACC range of \(7.5 - 8.5\%\) from 8.0- 8.5% previously.
Exhibit 8: Marginal changes in pipeline WACC across segment moves our pipeline EBITDA Changes in Grenergy estimates (€m, %)
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report

We also change the valuation framework we apply to derive our PO. We no longer apply an equally- weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple. Instead, we now solely use our DCF- based SOTP, as the 'fair' EV/EBITDA multiple analysis is complicated in our view between pipeline execution, asset rotation gains - especially given the size of the business. We have made similar changes for Solaria in our coverage.

We also apply a more conservative \(35 - 85\%\) pipeline discount vs \(30 - 75\%\) in our SOTP previously, as we rebalance the risk- reward across our coverage. Nevertheless, our SOTP fair value rises \(5\%\) driven by updates for liabilities and assets under construction.
Overall, our PO increases from €72.5 to €79.0.

Our PO for Acciona Energia is derived from an equally- weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €17.5.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(7 - 8\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and medium- term asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(50\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).

For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 8x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs \(8.5x Y+1\) median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables as well as caution on gross deployments and asset rotations more specifically for Acciona Energia.

Upside/downside to our PO are: wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

Our PO for EDPR is derived from an equally weighted average of a SOTP (DCF- based) and a group EV/EBITDA headline multiple, an approach that we think reflects the drivers of share prices for renewables. Our resulting PO is €7.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(6 - 6.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discount pipeline growth to 2030 by \(- 25\%\) and beyond by \(- 75\%\) (our base discount across our renewable coverage).
For our EV/EBITDA, we use a 10x 2026 Y+1 target multiple (vs \(8.2x Y+1\) median last 2 years) that reflects a mediocre backdrop for renewables.

Upside/downside to our PO are wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.
Our PO for Solaria is derived from a SOTP (DCF- based), an approach that we think reflects the underlying value creation potential and associated execution risks. Our resulting PO is €79.

For our SOTP, our DCFs are based on regional operating assets and future growth pipeline, with \(7.5 - 8.5\%\) WACC, 200- 300bps IRR spreads, and asset sale gains of \(30\%\) (over \(30\%\) of the pipeline). We discounted growth to 2030 by \(- 35\%\) and beyond by \(- 85\%\) (slightly higher medium- term than our \(- 25\%\) and \(- 75\%\) base case). We have separately modelled the Oasis Atacama project with no further sell down.

Upside/downside risks to our PO are: wind/solar load factors, power prices, renewables Capex, expected project awards and value creation spreads, returns on asset rotation deals, as well as regulation, delays in construction or permitting or any other political intervention more widely in the sector.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0-12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
